questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. HPV 18

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection . Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers. Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35. Genital warts , also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11) . These types, referred to as low-risk , have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.
  • • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection .
  • • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection
  • • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • • HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk
  • • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • • high-risk types
  • • HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • • Genital warts , also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11) . These types, referred to as low-risk , have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.
  • • Genital warts
  • • human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11)
  • • low-risk
  • • lower potential
  • • Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact , although non-sexual transmission is also possible .
  • • sexual contact
  • • non-sexual transmission
  • • possible
  • • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.
  • • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin
  • • IMIQUIMOD:
  • • IMIQUIMOD:
  • • Imiquimod cream uses: Actinic keratoses Superficial basal cell carcinoma Genital warts (topical immunomodulation) Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8 , leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • • Imiquimod cream uses: Actinic keratoses Superficial basal cell carcinoma Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
  • • Imiquimod cream uses:
  • • Actinic keratoses Superficial basal cell carcinoma Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
  • • Actinic keratoses
  • • Actinic keratoses
  • • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
  • • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
  • • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
  • • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
  • • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8 , leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • • Mechanism of action:
  • • toll-like receptors 7 and 8
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A HPV 2 :
  • • Option A HPV 2
  • • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet , not with anogenital warts or cancer.
  • • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet , not with anogenital warts or cancer.
  • • common warts
  • • hands and feet
  • • Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11 :
  • • Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11
  • • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer. They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.
  • • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
  • • 90% of genital
  • • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.
  • • respiratory papillomatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer. It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management. High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.
  • ➤ HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • ➤ HPV 16 & 18
  • ➤ high-risk types
  • ➤ anogenital cancers,
  • ➤ HPV 2, 6, and 11
  • ➤ low-risk
  • ➤ It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • ➤ differences in prognosis and management.
  • ➤ High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.
  • ➤ High-risk types
  • ➤ aggressive monitoring
  • ➤ malignancy.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Barium meal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given image is a barium meal. This study is used to examine the stomach and proximal duodenum.
  • • Visual Cues: The image shows the distribution of barium within the stomach, outlining its contours and revealing its internal structure, which is typical in a barium meal examination.
  • • Visual Cues:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow: This study primarily evaluates the esophagus and does not extend into the stomach. The radiograph showing the stomach filled with barium indicates that the procedure goes beyond just a barium swallow.
  • • Option A. Barium Swallow:
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through: This investigation involves not only the stomach but also a sequential imaging of the small intestine as the barium passes through. The specific image provided does not show barium beyond the proximal duodenum, which is typical in a simple barium meal.
  • • Option C. Barium Meal Follow Through:
  • • Option D. Barium Enema: This procedure is used to visualize the large intestine (colon) and rectum using barium introduced via the rectum. The provided image showing the stomach filled with barium clearly indicates that it's not a barium enema.
  • • Option D. Barium Enema:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room after consuming 8 digoxin tablets. On examination, he was found to be unstable, with a heart rate of 56 beats per minute. An ECG revealed a third-degree heart block. What is the next step in this patient's care? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Digoxin Immune Fab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The administration of Digoxin Immune Fab is the next step in the management of life-threatening digoxin toxicity, particularly in the presence of bradycardia and third-degree heart block.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris
  • ➤ flaccid bullae
  • ➤ rupture easily
  • ➤ suprabasal split
  • ➤ autoimmune
  • ➤ loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

questions.text: Which glands are primarily affected in Bromhidrosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.correct_answer: C. Both Apocrine and Eccrine Glands
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both Apocrine and Eccrine Glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor) can originate from both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet) , resulting from bacterial decomposition of sweat components on the skin surface.
  • ➤ Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor) can originate from both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet) , resulting from bacterial decomposition of sweat components on the skin surface.
  • ➤ Bromhidrosis (offensive body odor)
  • ➤ both apocrine glands (primarily in axillary regions) and eccrine glands (commonly on feet)

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.
  • ➤ The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with phenylketonuria with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase levels? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dihydrobiopterin reductase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In non-classical phenylketonuria, the deficiency is in dihydrobiopterin reductase, not phenylalanine hydroxylase.

questions.text: A bronchial asthma patient who is on inhalational steroids presented with white patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. What is the drug that can be used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Clotrimazole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clotrimazole is the drug of choice for treating oral candidiasis, especially in patients who develop the condition as a side effect of inhalational steroid use. It works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis, compromising the fungal cell membrane integrity.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 18 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On US, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Renal agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Early onset oligohydramnios can be due to renal anomalies like bilateral renal agenesis, bilateral dysplastic kidneys, or bilateral autosomal recessive infantile polycystic kidney disease.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 352, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: The cross product ratio can be obtained by: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Case control study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cross-product ratio, or odds ratio, is a measure of association commonly derived from case-control studies to determine the relationship between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.
  • ➤ Niacin deficiency can be caused by:
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency Carcinoid syndrome Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • ➤ Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • ➤ Carcinoid syndrome
  • ➤ Hartnup’s disease
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the image given below? ( NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Dermoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Recognizing and differentiating between various ocular surface lesions is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and management. This involves understanding their typical presentations, etiologies, and potential complications. Regular eye examinations and proper eye protection, especially from UV light, are important for eye health.

questions.text: Which drug is used for mass chemoprophylaxis for meningococcal meningitis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ciprofloxacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ciprofloxacin, Rifampicin, Ceftriaxone is indicated in the chemoprophylaxis of meningococcal meningitis for close contacts to prevent secondary cases.
  • ➤ Ceftriaxone is preferred in children < 18 years and pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the fibres in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Projection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with cough and congestion in the chest. He is a known case of atrial fibrillation (AF) and on examination, he had an irregularly irregular pulse and ECG showed AF with a heart rate of 52/min. His current medications are KCl 10 mEq BID, Triamterene, ASA 100mg/day, Atenolol 50 mg BID, and Clarithromycin. Two months ago, his digoxin levels were 1.5 ng/mL and currently, it rose to 3.4 ng/mL. Which of the following is responsible for such an increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Clarithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clarithromycin, by inhibiting CYP3A4, can significantly elevate digoxin levels, leading to toxicity. When prescribing medications, it is essential to consider potential drug-drug interactions, especially with drugs like digoxin that have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? (NEET PG 2022) Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1,2,3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:
  • ➤ Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response Evaluate the risk of disaster Information sessions coordination with news media Adopt standards and regulations
  • ➤ Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  • ➤ Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  • ➤ Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  • ➤ Evaluate the risk of disaster
  • ➤ Information sessions coordination with news media
  • ➤ Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 10 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201

questions.text: What makes CPDA superior than ACD for blood storage? ( NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

questions.correct_answer: A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The fall in 2, 3 DPG is less when the blood is stored in CPDA compared with ACD.
  • • The ease with which hemoglobin releases oxygen to the tissues is controlled by erythrocytic 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) such that an increase in the concentration of 2,3-DPG decreases oxygen affinity and vice versa.
  • • In stored blood, the 2,3 DPG levels usually fall, thus less oxygen is released to the tissues. Therefore, its use in hypoxic patients (E.g., anemia) is limited.
  • • Phosphate-containing solution like CPDA (Citrate, phosphate, dextrose, adenine) prevents the fall in 2.3DPG levels. Higher 2,3 DPG concentration decreases affinity of Hb to the oxygen releasing oxygen to the tissues.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Decreased release of O2 : Incorrect. The goal of effective blood storage solutions like CPDA is to ensure that the oxygen release capacity is maintained, not decreased. CPDA helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG, which enhances the release of oxygen to tissues.
  • • Option B. Decreased release of O2
  • • Option C. It has less P50 : Incorrect. P50 is a measure of the oxygen tension at which hemoglobin is 50% saturated with oxygen. A higher P50, indicative of lower oxygen affinity, is preferable in stored blood as it means oxygen is more readily released to tissues—a trait supported by higher 2,3-DPG levels.
  • • Option C. It has less P50
  • • Option D. It is less acidic : Incorrect. While pH maintenance is important in blood storage, the primary benefit of CPDA over ACD is not related to less acidity but to its inclusion of phosphate and adenine, which help sustain energy (ATP) production and 2,3-DPG levels in red blood cells.
  • • Option D. It is less acidic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The use of CPDA in blood storage is superior to ACD due to its phosphate content, which helps maintain higher levels of 2,3-DPG in stored red blood cells. This biochemical preservation is crucial for ensuring that transfused blood can effectively release oxygen to hypoxic tissues, making CPDA the preferred choice in clinical settings where blood transfusions are necessary.
